DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's statement in an AP news interview from February 1, 2025 that his country's military has received only a portion of the more than 175 billion in U.S. aid confirms that the US aid is a money laundering operation."

## Actions
```
image_search("AP news interview Volodymyr Zelenskyy February 1 2025 aid")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`
The AP News article ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-trump-talks-ceasefire-00af5f61f1faf41e78a3b4e072c21a14)) contains an image of Volodymyr Zelenskyy <image:7191>.

The Le Monde article ([Source](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/united-states/article/2025/02/28/trump-and-zelensky-openly-clash-in-heated-white-house-exchange_6738686_133.html)) also contains an image of Volodymyr Zelenskyy <image:7192>.


## Elaboration
The evidence includes two images of Volodymyr Zelenskyy, one from an AP News article ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-trump-talks-ceasefire-00af5f61f1faf41e78a3b4e072c21a14)) and another from a Le Monde article ([Source](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/united-states/article/2025/02/28/trump-and-zelensky-openly-clash-in-heated-white-house-exchange_6738686_133.html)). However, neither article provides information about Zelenskyy's statement regarding U.S. aid or confirms the claim that the aid is a money laundering operation.

The claim cannot be verified with the provided evidence. More information is needed to confirm the veracity of the claim.


## Actions
```
image_search("Volodymyr Zelenskyy AP news interview February 1 2025 US aid")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`
The search results include articles from AP News ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russian-ukraine-war-zelenskyy-news-conference-5440b3d3034a34461d93d0740e0c1ae6)), NPR ([Source](https://www.npr.org/2025/02/28/g-s1-51205/up-first-newsletter-ukraine-us-mineral-deal-andrew-tate-aoc)), and PBS ([Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/zelenskyy-to-meet-trump-on-monday-after-u-s-russia-summit-secured-no-halt-to-war-in-ukraine)). Each article contains an image of Volodymyr Zelenskyy <image:7198>, <image:7199>, <image:7200>. However, none of the provided summaries mention Zelenskyy's statement about U.S. aid or the claim that it is a money laundering operation.


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The new evidence, which includes articles from AP News ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russian-ukraine-war-zelenskyy-news-conference-5440b3d3034a34461d93d0740e0c1ae6)), NPR ([Source](https://www.npr.org/2025/02/28/g-s1-51205/up-first-newsletter-ukraine-us-mineral-deal-andrew-tate-aoc)), and PBS ([Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/zelenskyy-to-meet-trump-on-monday-after-u-s-russia-summit-secured-no-halt-to-war-in-ukraine)), does not support the claim. These articles feature images of Zelenskyy but do not contain any information about his statements regarding U.S. aid or the assertion that it is a money laundering operation.

The claim remains unverified due to the lack of supporting evidence.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's statement in an AP news interview from February 1, 2025 that his country's military has received only a portion of the more than 175 billion in U.S. aid confirms that the US aid is a money laundering operation."

## Actions
```
image_search("AP news interview Volodymyr Zelenskyy February 1 2025 aid")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`
The AP News article ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-trump-talks-ceasefire-00af5f61f1faf41e78a3b4e072c21a14)) contains an image of Volodymyr Zelenskyy <image:7191>.

The Le Monde article ([Source](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/united-states/article/2025/02/28/trump-and-zelensky-openly-clash-in-heated-white-house-exchange_6738686_133.html)) also contains an image of Volodymyr Zelenskyy <image:7192>.


## Elaboration
The evidence includes two images of Volodymyr Zelenskyy, one from an AP News article ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-trump-talks-ceasefire-00af5f61f1faf41e78a3b4e072c21a14)) and another from a Le Monde article ([Source](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/united-states/article/2025/02/28/trump-and-zelensky-openly-clash-in-heated-white-house-exchange_6738686_133.html)). However, neither article provides information about Zelenskyy's statement regarding U.S. aid or confirms the claim that the aid is a money laundering operation.

The claim cannot be verified with the provided evidence. More information is needed to confirm the veracity of the claim.


## Actions
```
image_search("Volodymyr Zelenskyy AP news interview February 1 2025 US aid")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`
The search results include articles from AP News ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russian-ukraine-war-zelenskyy-news-conference-5440b3d3034a34461d93d0740e0c1ae6)), NPR ([Source](https://www.npr.org/2025/02/28/g-s1-51205/up-first-newsletter-ukraine-us-mineral-deal-andrew-tate-aoc)), and PBS ([Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/zelenskyy-to-meet-trump-on-monday-after-u-s-russia-summit-secured-no-halt-to-war-in-ukraine)). Each article contains an image of Volodymyr Zelenskyy <image:7198>, <image:7199>, <image:7200>. However, none of the provided summaries mention Zelenskyy's statement about U.S. aid or the claim that it is a money laundering operation.


## Elaboration
The new evidence, which includes articles from AP News ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russian-ukraine-war-zelenskyy-news-conference-5440b3d3034a34461d93d0740e0c1ae6)), NPR ([Source](https://www.npr.org/2025/02/28/g-s1-51205/up-first-newsletter-ukraine-us-mineral-deal-andrew-tate-aoc)), and PBS ([Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/zelenskyy-to-meet-trump-on-monday-after-u-s-russia-summit-secured-no-halt-to-war-in-ukraine)), does not support the claim. These articles feature images of Zelenskyy but do not contain any information about his statements regarding U.S. aid or the assertion that it is a money laundering operation.

The claim remains unverified due to the lack of supporting evidence.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results provide images of Volodymyr Zelenskyy from various news sources, but none of the articles confirm the specific statement attributed to him in the claim. The claim cannot be verified because there is no evidence to support it.

`not enough information`

_________________________



PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's statement in an AP news interview from February 1, 2025 that his country's military has received only a portion of the more than 175 billion in U.S. aid confirms that the US aid is a money laundering operation."

## Actions
```
image_search("AP news interview Volodymyr Zelenskyy February 1 2025 aid")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`
The AP News article ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-trump-talks-ceasefire-00af5f61f1faf41e78a3b4e072c21a14)) contains an image of Volodymyr Zelenskyy <image:7191>.

The Le Monde article ([Source](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/united-states/article/2025/02/28/trump-and-zelensky-openly-clash-in-heated-white-house-exchange_6738686_133.html)) also contains an image of Volodymyr Zelenskyy <image:7192>.


## Elaboration
The evidence includes two images of Volodymyr Zelenskyy, one from an AP News article ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-trump-talks-ceasefire-00af5f61f1faf41e78a3b4e072c21a14)) and another from a Le Monde article ([Source](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/united-states/article/2025/02/28/trump-and-zelensky-openly-clash-in-heated-white-house-exchange_6738686_133.html)). However, neither article provides information about Zelenskyy's statement regarding U.S. aid or confirms the claim that the aid is a money laundering operation.

The claim cannot be verified with the provided evidence. More information is needed to confirm the veracity of the claim.


## Actions
```
image_search("Volodymyr Zelenskyy AP news interview February 1 2025 US aid")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`
The search results include articles from AP News ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russian-ukraine-war-zelenskyy-news-conference-5440b3d3034a34461d93d0740e0c1ae6)), NPR ([Source](https://www.npr.org/2025/02/28/g-s1-51205/up-first-newsletter-ukraine-us-mineral-deal-andrew-tate-aoc)), and PBS ([Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/zelenskyy-to-meet-trump-on-monday-after-u-s-russia-summit-secured-no-halt-to-war-in-ukraine)). Each article contains an image of Volodymyr Zelenskyy <image:7198>, <image:7199>, <image:7200>. However, none of the provided summaries mention Zelenskyy's statement about U.S. aid or the claim that it is a money laundering operation.


## Elaboration
The new evidence, which includes articles from AP News ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russian-ukraine-war-zelenskyy-news-conference-5440b3d3034a34461d93d0740e0c1ae6)), NPR ([Source](https://www.npr.org/2025/02/28/g-s1-51205/up-first-newsletter-ukraine-us-mineral-deal-andrew-tate-aoc)), and PBS ([Source](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/zelenskyy-to-meet-trump-on-monday-after-u-s-russia-summit-secured-no-halt-to-war-in-ukraine)), does not support the claim. These articles feature images of Zelenskyy but do not contain any information about his statements regarding U.S. aid or the assertion that it is a money laundering operation.

The claim remains unverified due to the lack of supporting evidence.

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1

# Example 2

# Example 3

The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's statement in an AP news interview from February 1, 2025 that his country's military has received only a portion of the more than 175 billion in U.S. aid confirms that the US aid is a money laundering operation."

However, none of the provided summaries mention Zelenskyy's statement about U.S. aid or the claim that it is a money laundering operation.

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's statement in an AP news interview from February 1, 2025 that his country's military has received only a portion of the more than 175 billion in U.S. aid confirms that the US aid is a money laundering operation."

## Elaboration
The evidence includes two images of Volodymyr Zelenskyy, one from an AP News article ([Source](https://apnews.com/article/russia-ukraine-war-trump-talks-ceasefire-00af5f61f1faf41e78a3b4e072c21a14)) and another from a Le Monde article ([Source](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/united-states/article/2025/02/28/trump-and-zelensky-openly-clash-in-heated-white-house-exchange_6738686_133.html)). However, neither article provides information about Zelenskyy's statement regarding U.S. aid or confirms the claim that the aid is a money laundering operation.

The claim cannot be verified with the provided evidence. More information is needed to confirm the veracity of the claim.

# Instructions

Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

## Claim
Claim: "Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's statement in an AP news interview from February 1, 2025 that his country's military has received only a portion of the more than 175 billion in U.S. aid confirms that the US aid is a money laundering operation."

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "During his visit to the White House in April 2025 Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced plans to resettle Palestinians in Gaza to Ukraine and Syria."

# Your Actions



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
```
image_search("Benjamin Netanyahu White House April 2025")
image_search("Benjamin Netanyahu Gaza Ukraine Syria resettlement")
```

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

image_search("Benjamin Netanyahu Gaza Ukraine Syria resettlement")
```

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Instructions

Always adhere to the following rules:

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "During his visit to the White House in April 2025 Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced plans to resettle Palestinians in Gaza to Ukraine and Syria."

## Actions
```
image_search("Benjamin Netanyahu White House April 2025")
image_search("Benjamin Netanyahu Gaza Ukraine Syria resettlement")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.stopfake.org/en/fake-israeli-prime-minister-netanyahu-proposed-to-resettle-gaza-residents-to-ukraine-and-syria/): 
Content: The search result from StopFake.org contains an image <image:7230> with the word "FAKE" overlaid on it. The image appears to show Benjamin Netanyahu and another person, and the text discusses the resettlement of Palestinians to Ukraine and Syria.


From [Source](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/netanyahu-orders-israeli-army-to-keep-control-of-syrias-demilitarized-buffer-zone-until-end-of-2025/3427726): 
Content: NONE


From [Source](https://thehill.com/opinion/4973704-netanyahu-gaza-resettlement/): 
Content: The search result contains an image of Benjamin Netanyahu <image:7231>.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
One source, StopFake.org, presents an image <image:7230> with the word "FAKE" overlaid, discussing the resettlement of Palestinians to Ukraine and Syria. Another source, The Hill, contains an image of Benjamin Netanyahu <image:7231>.

The other source ([https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/netanyahu-orders-israeli-army-to-keep-control-of-syrias-demilitarized-buffer-zone-until-end-of-2025/3427726](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/netanyahu-orders-israeli-army-to-keep-control-of-syrias-demilitarized-buffer-zone-until-end-of-2025/3427726)) does not contain any relevant information.

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "During his visit to the White House in April 2025 Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced plans to resettle Palestinians in Gaza to Ukraine and Syria."

## Actions
```
image_search("Benjamin Netanyahu White House April 2025")
image_search("Benjamin Netanyahu Gaza Ukraine Syria resettlement")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`
The Times of Israel ([https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog-april-7-2025/](https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog-april-7-2025/)) provides an image of Benjamin Netanyahu and Donald Trump shaking hands in the White House <image:7218>. NPR ([https://www.npr.org/2025/07/07/g-s1-76296/israel-netanyahu-meet-trump](https://www.npr.org/2025/07/07/g-s1-76296/israel-netanyahu-meet-trump)) contains an image of Benjamin Netanyahu and Donald Trump <image:7219>.

Al-Monitor ([https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2025/06/netanyahu-visit-white-house-gaza-truce-pressure-mounts](https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2025/06/netanyahu-visit-white-house-gaza-truce-pressure-mounts)) contains an image of Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House <image:7221>.


### Evidence from `image_search`
One source, StopFake.org, presents an image <image:7230> with the word "FAKE" overlaid, discussing the resettlement of Palestinians to Ukraine and Syria. Another source, The Hill, contains an image of Benjamin Netanyahu <image:7231>.

The other source ([https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/netanyahu-orders-israeli-army-to-keep-control-of-syrias-demilitarized-buffer-zone-until-end-of-2025/3427726](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/netanyahu-orders-israeli-army-to-keep-control-of-syrias-demilitarized-buffer-zone-until-end-of-2025/3427726)) does not contain any relevant information.


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence includes images of Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House, specifically with Donald Trump. However, the evidence also includes a "FAKE" image discussing the resettlement of Palestinians to Ukraine and Syria.

The evidence does not provide any information to support the claim that Netanyahu announced plans to resettle Palestinians in Gaza to Ukraine and Syria during his visit to the White House. The "FAKE" image suggests that this information is false.

Therefore, the claim is likely false.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "During his visit to the White House in April 2025 Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced plans to resettle Palestinians in Gaza to Ukraine and Syria."

## Actions
```
image_search("Benjamin Netanyahu White House April 2025")
image_search("Benjamin Netanyahu Gaza Ukraine Syria resettlement")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`
The Times of Israel ([https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog-april-7-2025/](https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog-april-7-2025/)) provides an image of Benjamin Netanyahu and Donald Trump shaking hands in the White House <image:7218>. NPR ([https://www.npr.org/2025/07/07/g-s1-76296/israel-netanyahu-meet-trump](https://www.npr.org/2025/07/07/g-s1-76296/israel-netanyahu-meet-trump)) contains an image of Benjamin Netanyahu and Donald Trump <image:7219>.

Al-Monitor ([https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2025/06/netanyahu-visit-white-house-gaza-truce-pressure-mounts](https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2025/06/netanyahu-visit-white-house-gaza-truce-pressure-mounts)) contains an image of Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House <image:7221>.


### Evidence from `image_search`
One source, StopFake.org, presents an image <image:7230> with the word "FAKE" overlaid, discussing the resettlement of Palestinians to Ukraine and Syria. Another source, The Hill, contains an image of Benjamin Netanyahu <image:7231>.

The other source ([https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/netanyahu-orders-israeli-army-to-keep-control-of-syrias-demilitarized-buffer-zone-until-end-of-2025/3427726](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/netanyahu-orders-israeli-army-to-keep-control-of-syrias-demilitarized-buffer-zone-until-end-of-2025/3427726)) does not contain any relevant information.


## Elaboration
The evidence includes images of Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House, specifically with Donald Trump. However, the evidence also includes a "FAKE" image discussing the resettlement of Palestinians to Ukraine and Syria.

The evidence does not provide any information to support the claim that Netanyahu announced plans to resettle Palestinians in Gaza to Ukraine and Syria during his visit to the White House. The "FAKE" image suggests that this information is false.

Therefore, the claim is likely false.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results show images of Netanyahu at the White House, but also a "FAKE" image related to the claim. There is no evidence to support the claim that Netanyahu announced plans to resettle Palestinians in Gaza to Ukraine and Syria.

`false`

SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "During his visit to the White House in April 2025 Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced plans to resettle Palestinians in Gaza to Ukraine and Syria."

## Actions
```
image_search("Benjamin Netanyahu White House April 2025")
image_search("Benjamin Netanyahu Gaza Ukraine Syria resettlement")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`
The Times of Israel ([https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog-april-7-2025/](https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog-april-7-2025/)) provides an image of Benjamin Netanyahu and Donald Trump shaking hands in the White House <image:7218>. NPR ([https://www.npr.org/2025/07/07/g-s1-76296/israel-netanyahu-meet-trump](https://www.npr.org/2025/07/07/g-s1-76296/israel-netanyahu-meet-trump)) contains an image of Benjamin Netanyahu and Donald Trump <image:7219>.

Al-Monitor ([https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2025/06/netanyahu-visit-white-house-gaza-truce-pressure-mounts](https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2025/06/netanyahu-visit-white-house-gaza-truce-pressure-mounts)) contains an image of Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House <image:7221>.


### Evidence from `image_search`
One source, StopFake.org, presents an image <image:7230> with the word "FAKE" overlaid, discussing the resettlement of Palestinians to Ukraine and Syria. Another source, The Hill, contains an image of Benjamin Netanyahu <image:7231>.

The other source ([https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/netanyahu-orders-israeli-army-to-keep-control-of-syrias-demilitarized-buffer-zone-until-end-of-2025/3427726](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/netanyahu-orders-israeli-army-to-keep-control-of-syrias-demilitarized-buffer-zone-until-end-of-2025/3427726)) does not contain any relevant information.


## Elaboration
The evidence includes images of Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House, specifically with Donald Trump. However, the evidence also includes a "FAKE" image discussing the resettlement of Palestinians to Ukraine and Syria.

The evidence does not provide any information to support the claim that Netanyahu announced plans to resettle Palestinians in Gaza to Ukraine and Syria during his visit to the White House. The "FAKE" image suggests that this information is false.

Therefore, the claim is likely false.


## Final Judgement
The search results show images of Netanyahu at the White House, but also a "FAKE" image related to the claim. There is no evidence to support the claim that Netanyahu announced plans to resettle Palestinians in Gaza to Ukraine and Syria.

`false`

## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim is false. While images confirm Benjamin Netanyahu's presence at the White House, a source explicitly labels information about resettling Palestinians to Ukraine and Syria as "FAKE" ([https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/netanyahu-orders-israeli-army-to-keep-control-of-syrias-demilitarized-buffer-zone-until-end-of-2025/3427726](https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/netanyahu-orders-israeli-army-to-keep-control-of-syrias-demilitarized-buffer-zone-until-end-of-2025/3427726)).

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock threatened the US with severing ties amid US President Donald Trump's comments on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Ukraine."

# Your Actions



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
```
image_search("Annalena Baerbock Donald Trump February 2025")
image_search("Annalena Baerbock threatens US sever ties")
```

Another source is from [Source](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/german-foreign-minister-europe-needs-be-involved-ukraine-talks-2025-02-13/) <image:6880>. SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock threatened the US with severing ties amid US President Donald Trump's comments on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Ukraine."

## Actions
```
image_search("Annalena Baerbock Donald Trump February 2025")
image_search("Annalena Baerbock threatens US sever ties")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.rferl.org/a/germany-china-baerbock-visit-war-ukraine-russia/33223503.html): 
Content: The search result contains an image of Annalena Baerbock. <image:6884>


From [Source](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/20/annalena-baerbock-the-german-minister-staring-down-russia-over-ukraine): 
Content: The Guardian published an article on January 20, 2022, about Annalena Baerbock. <image:6885>


From [Source](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-05/german-foreign-minister-annalena-baerbock-china-russia-trade/103802558): 
Content: The search result from ABC News features an image of Annalena Baerbock. <image:6886>


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results include articles and images of Annalena Baerbock. One source is from [Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty](https://www.rferl.org/a/germany-china-baerbock-visit-war-ukraine-russia/33223503.html) <image:6884>. Another source is from [The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/20/annalena-baerbock-the-german-minister-staring-down-russia-over-ukraine) <image:6885>.

Additionally, there is a result from [ABC News](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-05/german-foreign-minister-annalena-baerbock-china-russia-trade/103802558) <image:6886>.

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock threatened the US with severing ties amid US President Donald Trump's comments on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Ukraine."

## Actions
```
image_search("Annalena Baerbock Donald Trump February 2025")
image_search("Annalena Baerbock threatens US sever ties")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`
The search results include images of Annalena Baerbock. One source is from [Source](https://www.hudson.org/global-economy/what-i-heard-munich-ordinary-germans-long-trump-their-own-kenneth-weinstein) <image:6879>. Another source is from [Source](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/german-foreign-minister-europe-needs-be-involved-ukraine-talks-2025-02-13/) <image:6880>. A third source is from [Source](https://www.plenglish.com/news/2025/02/20/germany-criticizes-trump-for-calling-zelensky-a-dictator/) <image:6881>.


### Evidence from `image_search`
The search results include articles and images of Annalena Baerbock. One source is from [Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty](https://www.rferl.org/a/germany-china-baerbock-visit-war-ukraine-russia/33223503.html) <image:6884>. Another source is from [The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/20/annalena-baerbock-the-german-minister-staring-down-russia-over-ukraine) <image:6885>.

Additionally, there is a result from [ABC News](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-05/german-foreign-minister-annalena-baerbock-china-russia-trade/103802558) <image:6886>.


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence confirms that Annalena Baerbock was active in February 2025 and that she commented on Donald Trump's remarks regarding Zelenskyy. One source states that Germany criticized Trump for calling Zelenskyy a dictator [Source](https://www.plenglish.com/news/2025/02/20/germany-criticizes-trump-for-calling-zelensky-a-dictator/).

However, the evidence does not contain any information about Baerbock threatening the US with severing ties.

Therefore, the claim is not fully supported by the evidence. More information is needed to verify the claim.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock threatened the US with severing ties amid US President Donald Trump's comments on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Ukraine."

## Actions
```
image_search("Annalena Baerbock Donald Trump February 2025")
image_search("Annalena Baerbock threatens US sever ties")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `image_search`
The search results include images of Annalena Baerbock. One source is from [Source](https://www.hudson.org/global-economy/what-i-heard-munich-ordinary-germans-long-trump-their-own-kenneth-weinstein) <image:6879>. Another source is from [Source](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/german-foreign-minister-europe-needs-be-involved-ukraine-talks-2025-02-13/) <image:6880>. A third source is from [Source](https://www.plenglish.com/news/2025/02/20/germany-criticizes-trump-for-calling-zelensky-a-dictator/) <image:6881>.


### Evidence from `image_search`
The search results include articles and images of Annalena Baerbock. One source is from [Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty](https://www.rferl.org/a/germany-china-baerbock-visit-war-ukraine-russia/33223503.html) <image:6884>. Another source is from [The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/20/annalena-baerbock-the-german-minister-staring-down-russia-over-ukraine) <image:6885>.

Additionally, there is a result from [ABC News](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-05/german-foreign-minister-annalena-baerbock-china-russia-trade/103802558) <image:6886>.


## Elaboration
The evidence confirms that Annalena Baerbock was active in February 2025 and that she commented on Donald Trump's remarks regarding Zelenskyy. One source states that Germany criticized Trump for calling Zelenskyy a dictator [Source](https://www.plenglish.com/news/2025/02/20/germany-criticizes-trump-for-calling-zelensky-a-dictator/).

However, the evidence does not contain any information about Baerbock threatening the US with severing ties.

Therefore, the claim is not fully supported by the evidence. More information is needed to verify the claim.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results confirm that Annalena Baerbock was active in February 2025 and commented on Donald Trump's remarks regarding Zelenskyy. However, the evidence does not contain any information about Baerbock threatening the US with severing ties.

The claim is not fully supported by the evidence. More information is needed to verify the claim. `not enough information`

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

One source is from [Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty](https://www.rferl.org/a/germany-china-baerbock-visit-war-ukraine-russia/33223503.html) <image:6884>. Additionally, there is a result from [ABC News](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-05/german-foreign-minister-annalena-baerbock-china-russia-trade/103802558) <image:6886>.


## Elaboration
The evidence confirms that Annalena Baerbock was active in February 2025 and that she commented on Donald Trump's remarks regarding Zelenskyy. One source states that Germany criticized Trump for calling Zelenskyy a dictator [Source](https://www.plenglish.com/news/2025/02/20/germany-criticizes-trump-for-calling-zelensky-a-dictator/).

However, the evidence does not contain any information about Baerbock threatening the US with severing ties.

Therefore, the claim is not fully supported by the evidence. More information is needed to verify the claim.


## Actions
```
image_search("Annalena Baerbock sever ties US February 2025")
```

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock threatened the US with severing ties amid US President Donald Trump's comments on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Ukraine."

## Actions

A third source is from [Source](https://www.plenglish.com/news/2025/02/20/germany-criticizes-trump-for-calling-zelensky-a-dictator/) <image:6881>.

One source is from [Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty](https://www.rferl.org/a/germany-china-baerbock-visit-war-ukraine-russia/33223503.html) <image:6884>. PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

However, the evidence does not contain any information about Baerbock threatening the US with severing ties.

Therefore, the claim is not fully supported by the evidence. More information is needed to verify the claim.

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock threatened the US with severing ties amid US President Donald Trump's comments on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Ukraine."

### Evidence from `image_search`
The search results include articles and images of Annalena Baerbock. One source is from [Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty](https://www.rferl.org/a/germany-china-baerbock-visit-war-ukraine-russia/33223503.html) <image:6884>. Another source is from [The Guardian](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/20/annalena-baerbock-the-german-minister-staring-down-russia-over-ukraine) <image:6885>.

## Elaboration
The evidence confirms that Annalena Baerbock was active in February 2025 and that she commented on Donald Trump's remarks regarding Zelenskyy. One source states that Germany criticized Trump for calling Zelenskyy a dictator [Source](https://www.plenglish.com/news/2025/02/20/germany-criticizes-trump-for-calling-zelensky-a-dictator/).

JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.

SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In February 2025 German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock threatened the US with severing ties amid US President Donald Trump's comments on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Ukraine."

```

```

Another source from The New Indian Express includes an image of Donald Trump and Volodymyr Zelenskyy (<image:7252>). Therefore, the claim is not supported by the evidence.


## Final Judgement
The search results confirm that Annalena Baerbock was active in February 2025 and commented on Donald Trump's remarks regarding Zelenskyy. However, the evidence does not contain any information about Baerbock threatening the US with severing ties. Therefore, the claim is not supported by the evidence.

`false`

## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The fact-check reveals that while Annalena Baerbock was active and commented on Donald Trump's remarks about Zelenskyy in February 2025, as evidenced by sources like [Source](https://www.plenglish.com/news/2025/02/20/germany-criticizes-trump-for-calling-zelensky-a-dictator/), there is no evidence to support the claim that she threatened to sever ties with the US.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In an interview with podcaster Theo Von in August 2024, Donald Trump criticized British Prime Minister Keir Starmer over a 100-year deal between the U.K. and Ukraine."

# Your Actions



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
```
image_search("Theo Von Donald Trump interview August 2024")
image_search("Donald Trump Keir Starmer Ukraine deal")
```

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.nsnews.com/local-news/theo-von-vancouver-donald-trump-interview-2024-9379843): 
Content: The search result from [Source](https://www.nsnews.com/local-news/theo-von-vancouver-donald-trump-interview-2024-9379843) contains an image of Donald Trump being interviewed by Theo Von. <image:7256>


From [Source](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/donald-trump-cocaine-theo-von-podcast-b2599472.html): 
Content: The Independent published an article about Donald Trump's interview with Theo Von. <image:7257>


From [Source](https://www.foxnews.com/politics/trump-talks-cocaine-biden-health-care-interview-comedian-theo-von): 
Content: Fox News reports on an interview with Donald Trump and comedian Theo Von. <image:7258>


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results indicate that Donald Trump was interviewed by Theo Von. One source includes an image of the interview (<image:7256>), while another source is an article from The Independent about the interview (<image:7257>). Fox News also reported on the interview (<image:7258>).

The articles can be found at the following URLs: [Source](https://www.nsnews.com/local-news/theo-von-vancouver-donald-trump-interview-2024-9379843), [Source](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/donald-trump-cocaine-theo-von-podcast-b2599472.html), and [Source](https://www.foxnews.com/politics/trump-talks-cocaine-biden-health-care-interview-comedian-theo-von).

# Instructions

# Record
## Claim

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://www.reuters.com/world/uks-starmer-discussed-tough-fair-ukraine-peace-deal-with-trump-2025-02-27/): 
Content: Reuters published an article about Keir Starmer and Donald Trump discussing a Ukraine peace deal. <image:7265>

Content: CNN published an article on February 27, 2025, about Donald Trump and Keir Starmer. <image:7266>

NBC News has an image of Donald Trump shaking hands with an individual, with flags of the United States and the United Kingdom in the background (<image:7267>).

The articles can be found at the following URLs: [Source](https://www.reuters.com/world/uks-starmer-discussed-tough-fair-ukraine-peace-deal-with-trump-2025-02-27/), [Source](https://www.cnn.com/2025/02/27/politics/trump-starmer-security-guarantees-analysis), and [Source](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/keir-starmer-sees-value-trumps-pursuit-ukrainian-mineral-rights-deal-rcna194047).
